annotations.paragraph: One way I’ve been thinking about this is in terms of a phrase that is traditionally applied to the left: counterculture. I think the best way to understand politics right now is that the United States, for the first time in my lifetime, has a real right-wing counterculture — an edgy, radical-seeming alternative to the status quo.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces the concept of a right-wing counterculture, which is central to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: I thought one way to talk about that counterculture was to invite someone who I see — we’ll see if he disagrees — as one of its representatives. And that’s you, Jonathan Keeperman, welcome to “Interesting Times.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a key figure related to the article's topic, contributing to the narrative progression.

annotations.paragraph: The left has dictated culture for decades. Jonathan Keeperman is trying to change that.

annotations.paragraph: I do want to point out that in 2020, when we first were having this dialogue and debate over the election, you also had something of a pseudonym. annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant context about past opinions and debates related to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: For me, Italics Ross was not the true Ross lurking below the surface. That wasn’t how I thought about it. I thought about it as a set of ideas that certainly existed in my consciousness and that were really useful for understanding where American culture was and why people supported Trump, and which New York Times readers needed to engage with.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the author's rationale for his writing approach, which is relevant to the article's exploration of cultural and political themes.

annotations.paragraph: I’m curious, before we dig into the ideas themselves, was there a moment when you felt a shift in the culture in the last few years when it seemed like you were going to exist as yourself as a public figure instead of as an anonymous arguer online?
annotations.reason: The paragraph is a question that sets up the interview but does not provide new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: Yeah, it’s a good question when that might have happened. There certainly was a shift. But what’s probably happening here is just the same old cycle of leftist excess that we’ve seen periodically over the course of American history, at least going back to the Second World War and probably even before that.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides context about historical cycles of leftist excess, which is relevant to the discussion of cultural shifts.

annotations.paragraph: There’s a decade of leftism that takes hold and creates a counterculture. There’s a period of pushback — we saw this, for example, with the original neocons in the ’70s. We see the cycle then play out again in the ’90s with political correctness — another 10-year cycle. Then all we’re seeing is this same pattern emerge in the mid-2010s — I identify 2014 as this inflection point. That was the year of Michael Brown and Ferguson and the rise of B.L.M.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides historical context and identifies a specific inflection point relevant to the cultural shift being discussed.

annotations.paragraph: It’s also this interesting period where the academy, at least — and I think probably this is happening within newspapers and media — is coming out of this interesting transition into the digital age and out of the recession, and there’s new incentives driving the content. What happens is that a bunch of conservatives — and especially younger conservatives, who are frozen out of the conservative movement and mainstream politics and the kinds of professions where they might have a platform to express new ideas that might regenerate conservatism — go online and go underground and start developing a unique and native style of discourse all our own.
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses the transition to digital media and the emergence of a new conservative discourse, which is relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: As that cycle of progressivism naturally exhausts itself — which it always does, and it takes a new form each time, but it always follows the same plot — what we’re seeing now is the emergence of this conservative counter-elite or countercultural force emerging in place of where the progressives have vacated.
annotations.reason: The paragraph describes the emergence of a conservative countercultural force, directly related to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: We can come up with all sorts of —
annotations.reason: The paragraph is incomplete and does not provide any information.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: What are we trying to do? We’re trying to revive what is a genuine right-wing cultural and ideological — I hate the word “movement,” because it’s not quite that — but a right wing that can form an enduring and meaningful counterweight to a dominant left and a dominant progressive march that we’ve seen taking place over the course of the postwar period, certainly from the ’90s and the end of the Cold War up until now.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into the goals and motivations of the new right-wing culture.

annotations.paragraph: The premise is that the conservatism that came before — I was recently looking at a picture online of a book called “Young Guns,” featuring Paul Ryan, Eric Cantor —
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a comparison to past conservatism, setting up context for the new movement.

annotations.reason: This paragraph confirms familiarity with a reference but does not add new information.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: Yes, that’s the image of the failed conservative movement that this new set of figures and cultural texts are trying to replace.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: Let’s try and get into what is an authentic cultural right. To me, Passage Press and the work you’re doing is clearly linked to a bunch of different groups. There is the Red Scare podcast and the so-called Dime Square scene in New York, which is basically — for those who think this is a contradiction in terms — it’s basically right-wing hipsters.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context and examples of groups and figures associated with the new cultural right, which is relevant to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: Yeah.

Those would be examples that I would see. But who do you see as your allies and fellow travelers in the cultural project?
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces another figure associated with the cultural right and asks a question that could lead to further relevant information.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: That’s absolutely right. I think you’ve hit the primary people and figures. You’re capturing what the zeitgeist is here, for lack of a better term. It’s still being developed, and I’d be lying to you if I said that I had some intentional project or aesthetic that I was trying to cultivate with this.
annotations.reason: This paragraph confirms the relevance of the mentioned figures and provides insight into the evolving nature of the cultural right.

annotations.paragraph: The idea is that the future is discovered. We’re not going to be able to predict ahead of time what this new culture will look like. It is throwing these ingredients out there based on a shared understanding at the highest level of abstraction, an alignment that, at least for now, is defined in opposition of both the left and wokeness — which is easy — but also in opposition to the conservatism that has come before, not because it’s antagonistic toward that kind of conservatism, per se, but that kind of conservatism is limited in what can produce creatively.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into the philosophical underpinnings and oppositional stance of the new cultural right, which is relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: A lot of the frustration that people have had with the right is that anytime anyone on the conservative side goes to make some kind of art or do culture, it’s just bad. The left is right about this. There’s been, at least for my lifetime, this critique that the right can’t do art, that the right can’t do culture.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the critique of right-wing art and culture, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: Why is that? What is right-wing art missing that the right-wing counterculture is trying to supply? What are the ingredients?
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces questions that drive the narrative forward.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: It’s not historically true, but at least recently.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a counterpoint to the previous statement, contributing to the discussion.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: In the last 30, 40 years, let’s say.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a timeframe for the discussion, adding context.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: I think partly it’s fear of the unknown. It’s a lack of tolerance for artistic license and the messiness and chaos of what is entailed by the creative process. And it’s just the case that if you are going to embark on a new cultural project, you have to have some amount of taste for offense.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers an explanation for the perceived shortcomings in right-wing art, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: And OK, I’ll say this. There’s probably three aspects to why conservative art is bad or has been bad. This is reductive of course, but this might help sort of frame things.
annotations.reason: The paragraph introduces a framework for discussing conservative art, which is relevant to the article's exploration of right-wing culture.

annotations.paragraph: It’s moralistic. OK? It’s much too moralistic. It’s didactic. It’s always trying to tell you a self-consciously conservative message. It’s overly sentimental.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific characteristics of conservative art, contributing to the article's analysis.

annotations.paragraph: There’s also this nostalgia thing. It’s always looking backward. Conservative art is always looking to the past because it’s familiar, it’s something that’s already been established. They already know what they’re supposed to like, what’s good and what’s not good, so there’s no risk in trying anything new.
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses the nostalgic aspect of conservative art, adding depth to the article's examination.

annotations.paragraph: The third thing I’ll say here is that it’s grievance oriented. This comes in two forms: it’s either “we’re owning the libs” or “here’s a story about all of the ways the libs are making our lives unbearable.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph identifies another characteristic of conservative art, which is relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: I want to make this just a tiny bit more concrete and say from any period, not the last 20 years, any period in American life, in modern Western history, give me an example of something you consider successful right-wing art that doesn’t fall into the traps you’ve described.
annotations.reason: The paragraph poses a question that seeks to further the discussion on conservative art, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: Sure. “No Country for Old Men” is an example, but it’s not self-consciously right wing.
annotations.reason: The paragraph introduces a cultural reference relevant to the discussion of right-wing art.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: Right, right.
annotations.reason: This is a filler response that does not add new information.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: I doubt the Coen Brothers would call themselves on the right, and I don’t even know if Cormac McCarthy would, who wrote the book it’s based on. But to my mind, it is precisely right-wing art. Or David Lynch — pretty much everything David Lynch touches has a certain right-wing coding to it, certainly his major works.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides examples and personal interpretation relevant to the discussion of right-wing art.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: What is the coding? To a listener for whom it seems absurd to call “No Country for Old Men” right wing, what makes that right wing to you?
annotations.reason: The paragraph poses a question that seeks to clarify the argument about right-wing art.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: Because I like it, it’s good, and therefore I want it to share my political preferences.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a subjective and somewhat humorous explanation of the speaker's view.

annotations.paragraph: Beyond that — and this is where there would be some points of disagreement —
annotations.reason: The paragraph is incomplete and does not provide any new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: By the way, I also call something like the TV show “Girls” a right-wing show.
annotations.reason: This statement is a personal opinion and does not contribute directly to the main premise.

annotations.reason: This is a conversational question that does not provide new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: Then we might share the premise here that what constitutes “right-wing art” — which is, by the way, labeling we’re grafting onto this thing after the fact, so it’s actually a very flimsy labeling, but what these pieces of work are doing is telling the truth about the world in a way that is not compromised by artistic or ideological preferences about how these events and these characters and these people, what society wishes were true about these people.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the concept of right-wing art and its relation to truth-telling, which is relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: My thing is that if you are telling the truth about the world, then you are going to make right-wing art.
annotations.reason: This statement contributes to the discussion on the nature of right-wing art, aligning with the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: Isn’t that then a little circular? Then you’re saying that all great art is somehow right wing.
annotations.reason: This paragraph questions the logic of equating truth-telling with right-wing art, adding depth to the discussion.

annotations.paragraph: To me, for instance, I feel like a TV show that I’ve enjoyed, “Andor” — one of the few “Star Wars” shows that I’ve enjoyed — I see it as left-wing art. It’s a show that uses the background of the Empire and the “Star Wars” universe to tell a story about punishing militaristic tyranny and resistance to it in ways that are left coded, but also it’s a really good show. Whereas I would look at “Girls” and say, in the end, it’s a scabrous satire of a particular kind of upper-middle-class lifestyle in a liberal city, so it is coming from a right-wing perspective.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides examples of art perceived as left-wing and right-wing, contributing to the discussion on cultural perspectives.

annotations.paragraph: Can be great left-wing art from your perspective?
annotations.reason: This question invites further exploration of the concept of left-wing art, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: I suppose, yeah. I’ll say this, I think it depends. I understand your point that it’s highly reductive to simply say, if I like it, it’s therefore right-wing art. Or if it tells the truth —
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a discussion on the nature of right-wing art and its relation to truth, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: It tells the truth, is what you’re saying. Yeah.
annotations.reason: This is a brief interjection that does not add new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: What I mean by that, though, is there are certain at least modern left-wing premises that support their worldview and their political agenda that I think are belied by someone telling the truth about the world.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a critique of left-wing premises, contributing to the discussion of right-wing culture.

annotations.paragraph: Here’s an example of this. The left takes as a foundational principle of its politics the idea of equality, that there’s a flattening of people, and that through carefully managed social engineering, we can produce a society that either levels out any kind of natural hierarchy or produce a system that somehow can wrangle these natural, almost supernatural entropic forces that are constantly creating chaos and constantly requiring our maintenance and management and authority to deal with.
annotations.reason: This paragraph elaborates on the critique of left-wing principles, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: OK, good. That’s what I was looking for. This takes us into one of the phrases that I think gets used to describe what the counterculture is up to. I know you’re ambivalent about this phrase — it’s the idea that gets called vitalism. It’s this term that means a celebration of individuality, strength, excellence, and an anxiety about equality and democracy as — just the way you described — as leveling forces and enemies of human greatness.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces the concept of vitalism, directly related to the article's exploration of right-wing culture.

annotations.paragraph: It gets connected to Friedrich Nietzsche. I think Ayn Rand, who’s a very popular novelist on the American right — whatever you make of her actual books — is in some sense in this school. That to me seems like one common thread, including in the books that you yourself have published. What links the White Russian general standing athwart the Bolsheviks to the Hardy Boys to Conan and Barbarian? It is some kind of idea of human greatness beset by mediocrity and so on.
annotations.reason: Provides context and examples related to the new culture of the right.

annotations.paragraph: What do you think about that?
annotations.reason: A low-information question without context or contribution.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: I think that’s right. I wouldn’t contest that basic summary. I don’t want to overdo how we’re thinking about this word “vitality.” For the purposes of this conversation, it’s enough to say it’s something like a thymos, OK? Spiritedness, a self-will, aliveness.
annotations.reason: Provides direct commentary on the concept of vitality in the context of the right.

annotations.paragraph: I also want to say that there’s a certain eroticism to vitality that’s very important and has often been missing from the conservative view of the world.
annotations.reason: Adds a new perspective on the concept of vitality in conservative thought.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: Yep.
annotations.reason: A low-information response without context or contribution.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: I think that’s a mistake. I think you’re leaving something very important on the table by not grappling with this notion of eroticism and what that means and why it might be valuable, especially since the premise we’re starting from — and I think, Ross, we share this view — is that we’re reaching a phase, whether it’s cyclical or there’s a longer-term linear path, of civilizational exhaustion, decay, decadence — that’s a word I know you’ve used a lot — and this all requires rebirth. And the process of rebirth is not gentle. It can be violent and difficult.
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses the themes of civilizational exhaustion and rebirth, which are relevant to the article's exploration of the new culture of the right.

annotations.paragraph: I would say that vitality serves two basic functions right now; it’s why it’s valuable for us to take on board. One, it attracts young people. Young people — I think men in particular,  women, too, though — are naturally attracted to this notion of vitality. They see it, they know it, and they want to be around it. The right has failed for a long time to attract young people. This is finally changing over the last few years.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides insight into how the concept of vitality is attracting young people to the right, which is relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: It’s also a way of overcoming a kind of defeatism of this idea that things are past the point of saving, that we can’t do anything, and that all there is left for us in the 21st century is to merely manage playing out this “end of history” period.
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses overcoming defeatism, which ties into the article's exploration of the right's new cultural dynamics.

annotations.paragraph: This sense of vitality, I think, offers something else. It offers the human subject the opportunity to advance positively and affirmatively into the future. That’s my defense of vitalism.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides a defense of vitalism, which is relevant to the article's discussion on the new culture of the right.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: And it’s an escape from — and now I’m going to move to a second term that you yourself have used — what gets called the longhouse. You mentioned men and women as each vital in certain ways, but the longhouse is a specifically feminine-coded narrative of what’s wrong with contemporary life. What is the longhouse?
annotations.reason: The paragraph introduces the concept of the longhouse, which is relevant to the article's exploration of cultural narratives on the right.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: So I wrote this essay called, “What is the longhouse?” for First Things magazine.
annotations.reason: Mentions an essay but does not contribute new information.

annotations.paragraph: Douthat: So you can answer the question, yes.
annotations.reason: A brief exchange without substantive content.

annotations.paragraph: Keeperman: I would encourage anybody who wants to know the precise details to go read that article because I spell out what I mean by it. annotations.paragraph: What one book sort of encapsulates what I’m trying to accomplish with this? annotations.paragraph: The book I would choose for this is “Moby-Dick.” It’s a very obvious, clichéd choice, but it’s a book that everybody from all ages, if you’re an American, should know. annotations.paragraph: My counterpoint to that — which I think is a nice coda — is that “No Country for Old Men” would be the movie. “Moby-Dick” is conquest and it’s the Atlantic, and now Cormac McCarthy and “No Country for Old Men,” the Coen Brothers film, is the border, the terminus of the West, the border with Mexico. It’s also late epic. It’s the exhaustion of American conquest. And there’s this force at the center of the book — this inscrutable, mysterious, supernatural force.
